Name: Sodium
Additional information related to SSI re:
This value is considered a safe and adequate intake of sodium. The reference value is called safe because it takes account of the evidence describing the relationship between sodium intake and CVD risk in the general population and adequate in line with the definition of an Adequate Intake. 
The value provides guidance on a level of sodium intake compatible with good health that can inform population goals for sodium. However, the value has limited utility for assessing and planning the diet of individuals. At the individual level, if the usual intake of sodium exceeds this value, it could be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, including concurring risk factors such as primary hypertension.

Name: Folate
AUTHOR: Scientific Committee on Food/Scientific Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition, Allergies
Scientific Opinion on DRV: Scientific Opinion on Dietary Reference Values for folate
Additional information related to AR/PRI:
Values relate to food folate and folic acid.
DFE: dietary folate equivalents. Natural food folates have a lower bioavailability than folic acid. DFE have been introduced to account for these differences.  For combined intakes of food folate and folic acid, DFEs can be computed as follows: g DFE =+ g food folate + (1.7 x g folic acid).
Scientific Opinion on the Tolerable Uppe: Tolerable Upper Intake Levels for Vitamins and Minerals

Name: Niacin
AUTHOR: Scientific Committee on Food/Scientific Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition, Allergies
Scientific Opinion on DRV: Scientific Opinion on Dietary Reference Values for niacin
Additional information related to AR/PRI:
Values relate to niacin in the form of nicotinamide and nicotinic acid. Niacin can be synthesised in the human body from the indispensable amino acid tryptophan.
NE: niacin equivalent (1 NE = 1 mg niacin = 60 mg dietary tryptophan)

Niacin requirement is related to energy requirement and therefore expressed in mg NE/MJ. Values expressed in mg NE/day can be calculated based on the energy requirement of the group considered (EFSA NDA Panel, 2013).
Scientific Opinion on the Tolerable Uppe: Tolerable Upper Intake Levels for Vitamins and Minerals

Name: Vitamin A
AUTHOR: Scientific Committee on Food/Scientific Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition, Allergies
Scientific Opinion on DRV: Scientific Opinion on Dietary Reference Values for vitamin A
Additional information related to AR/PRI:
Values relate to vitamin A in the form of retinol, retinyl esters and provitamin A carotenoids.
RE: retinol equivalent. Provitamin A carotenoids have a lower bioavailability than retinol. In order to take into account these differences, RE have been introduced and defined as 1 g RE = 1 g of retinol = 6 g of -carotene = 12 g of other carotenoids with provitamin A activity.
Scientific Opinion on the Tolerable Uppe: Tolerable Upper Intake Levels for Vitamins and Minerals
